The Sudzhuq-Kale War took place in 1720, marking the first major Ottoman attempt to expand influence into Western Circassia and Kabarda.
History
In the spring of 1720, the Crimean Khanate under Saadet II Giray led a 40,000-strong army into Kabarda and Western Circassia. This was one of the largest Crimean invasions of Kabarda. The Khan demanded tribute from every household and asked Kabardian princes and their subjects to resettle along the Kuban River. The Kabardians refused to pay tribute. Crimean forces raided, plundered, and burned parts of Kabarda.
At the same time, the Ottoman Empire built the fortress of Sudzhuq-Kale (modern Novorossiysk) to strengthen its influence in the region. Circassian and Kabardian leaders resisted both Ottoman and Crimean demands, maintaining significant independence despite the military pressure.
